facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 156 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1963 of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application No. 315 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 156 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1963 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  in Special Civil Application No. 315 of 1962.

facts.text: Model Mills, Nagpur is a public limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Model Mills, Nagpur  hereinafter referred to as the Mills  is a public limited companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act.

facts.text: On July 18, 1959, the Central Government took over the management of the Mills under s. 18-A of the Industries Development and Regulation Act, 1951 and appointed the 3rd respondent as authorised Controller.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1959, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 18-A of the Industries  Development and Regulation  Act, 1951, the Central Government took over the management of the Mills and appointed the 3rd respondent as the authorised Controller of the Mills.

facts.text: On March 25, 1960, the State of Bombay notified the Mills as a relief undertaking for one year from March 26, 1960 to March 25, 1961 under ss. 3 and 4 of the Bombay Relief Undertakings Special Provisions Act, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1960 the State of Bombay  number the State of Maharashtra , in exercise of the powers companyferred by ss. 3 and 4 of the Bombay Relief Undertakings  Special Provisions  Act, 1958  hereinafter referred to as the Bombay Act  made a numberification declaring the Mills to be a relief undertaking for a period of one year companymencing from March 26, 1960 and ending with March 25, 1961.

facts.text: The appellants are eight permanent employees of the Mills.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, eight in number, were, at the relevant time, the permanent employees of the Mills.

facts.text: On December 15, 1960, the employees abstained from work while the notification under the Bombay Act was in force.

anchor.surface_text: It would be companyvenient to refer to them as employees. On December 15, 1960, when the numberification made by the State Government under the Bombay Act was in force, the employees abstained from work.

facts.text: The 1st respondent, Factory Manager of the Mills, issued notices to the employees to show cause why they should not be dismissed for joining an illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the 1st respondent who is the Factory Manager of the Mills issued numberices to the employees to show cause why they should number be dismissed from service for joining an illegal strike.

facts.text: On January 6, 1961, the Factory Manager dismissed the employees from service.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1961 the Factory Manager passed orders dismissing the employees from service.

facts.text: On January 12, 1961, the employees filed an application in the Bombay High Court for a writ of mandamus directing reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1961 the employees filed an application in the High Court of Bombay for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the employees to be reinstated in service.

facts.text: On April 4, 1961, the exemption of the Mills from s. 16 of the Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 was withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4, 1961, the exemption of the Mills from the application of s. 16 of the Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act  XXIII of 1947   herein- after called the State Act  was made.

facts.text: On April 25, 1961, the employees filed applications before the Assistant Commissioner of Labour for reinstatement with back wages.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1961 the employees filed applications before the Assistant Commissioner Sup.CI./76-12 of Labour claiming reinstatement with back wages.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the writ petition filed by the employees with liberty to file fresh petition, as they were pursuing applications before the Assistant Commissioner of Labour.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the Writ Petition filed by the employees with liberty to file a fresh petition, if necessary, since they were prosecuting their applications for relief of reinstatement before the Assistant Commissioner of Labour.

facts.text: On September 29, 1961, the Assistant Commissioner allowed the employees' applications, held no illegal strike, set aside dismissal orders, and directed reinstatement with back wages.

anchor.surface_text: In and by his order dated September 29, 1961, the Assistant Commissioner allowed the applications filed by the employees. He held that as there was numberillegal strike the orders of dismissal were unsustainable and should be set aside.

facts.text: The Mills filed revision applications against the Assistant Commissioner's orders to the State Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the orders passed by the Assistant Commissioner, the Mills preferred applications in revision to the State Industrial Court.

facts.text: On February 16, 1962, the State Industrial Court allowed the Mills' revision applications on ground of non-maintainability, but agreed there was no illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated February 16, 1962, the Industrial Court allowed the revision applications filed by the Mills on the ground that the applications before the Assistant Commissioner were number maintainable.

facts.text: The employees filed application under Arts. 226 and 227 for writ of certiorari to quash dismissal orders and direct reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the orders of the Industrial Court, the employees filed an applicaton under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the orders of dismissal passed by the Factory Manager and to direct their reinstatement with back wages.

facts.text: On August 12, 1963, the Bombay High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated August 12, 1963 the High Court dismissed the Writ Petition filed by the employees.

facts.text: The notification declaring Mills relief undertaking was extended on March 8, 1961 for a further one year.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification was extended by the State Government on March 8, 1961 for a further period of one year.

facts.text: The alleged participation by employees in illegal strike occurred on December 15, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The alleged participation by the employees in an illegal strike occurred on December 15, 1960 and the 1st respondent dismissed the employees in and by his order dated January 6, 1961.

facts.text: The Supreme Court set aside the High Court judgment and Industrial Court order, restored the Assistant Commissioner of Labour's award.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the judgment of the High Court and the order of the Industrial Court are set aside and the award made by the Assistant Commissioner of Labour is restored.

facts.text: The Assistant Commissioner and Industrial Court found there was no illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: He held that as there was numberillegal strike... On the merits, the Industrial Court agreed with the Assistant Commissioner that there was numberillegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that s. 16 is made applicable to the textile industry with effect from. March 1, 1951 by a numberification dated February 22, 1951.

facts.text: Employees filed applications within six months from dismissal date.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellants filed their applications within the period specified in S. 16 of the State Act.

issues.text: Whether the right of a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement, in appropriate cases, exists de hors s. 16 of the State Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the right of a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement, in appropriate cases, exists. de hors s. 16 of the State Act ?

issues.text: Whether by reason of the State Governments exemption of the industry from the operation of s. 16 on the date when the employees were dismissed from service, their right to apply for reinstatement ceased to exist?

anchor.surface_text: Whether by reason of the State Governments exemption of the industry from the operation of s. 16 on the date when the employees were dismissed from service, their right to apply for reinstatement ceased to exist ?

issues.text: Whether the effect of the exemption granted under the Bombay Act is to destroy the right to reinstatement or merely to suspend the remedy under s. 16 of the State Act?
Whether the employees' applications under s. 16 were filed within the six months period from dismissal and thus maintainable after withdrawal of exemption?

anchor.surface_text: Once the exemption is withdrawn the status quo ante is restored and it is open to the employee to file an application for reinstatement provided, however, his application is within the period of six months from the date of his dismissal.

holdings.text: The right of an employee to claim reinstatement on a wrongful dismissal exists de hors s. 16 of the State Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16 recognises pre-existing right under common law and Industrial Disputes Act precedents like Federal Court in Western India Automobile; provides forum and procedure, not creation of right.

holdings.text: Section 16 provides a forum for a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement but does not create a right.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 provides a forum for a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement but does not create a right. The effect of an exemption granted by the notification issued under the Bombay Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.16; historical recognition post-1947 Industrial Disputes Act; distinguishes creation from enforcement.

holdings.text: The effect of an exemption granted by the notification issued under the Bombay Act is not to destroy the right but to suspend the remedy prescribed by s. 16 for enforcing that right during the period when the exemption remains in force.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of an exemption granted by the notification issued under the Bombay Act is not to destroy the right but to suspend the remedy prescribed by s. 16 for enforcing that right during the period when the exemption remains in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemption targets procedural remedy under s.16, not substantive right; dictionary meanings rejected in favor of legal effect; harmonious construction with Bombay Act ss.3-4.

holdings.text: The right can be enforced by a dismissed employee by resorting to the provisions of s. 16 of the Act provided he makes the application within six months from the date of his dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The right can be enforced by a dismissed employee by resorting to the provisions of s. 16 of the Act provided he makes the application within six months from the date of his dismissal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Withdrawal restores status quo ante; no retrospectivity issue as right pre-existed; analogy to continuing disputes in Birla Brothers.

holdings.text: In the present case, the appellants filed their applications within the period specified in S. 16 of the State Act. The High Court was in error in holding that the applications were not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellants filed their applications within the period specified in S. 16 of the State Act. The High Court was in error in holding that the applications were not maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show dismissal Jan 6, 1961; applications Apr 25, 1961; exemption withdrawn Apr 4, 1961; timely post-restoration.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court and the order of the Industrial Court are set aside and the award made by the Assistant Commissioner of Labour is restored.
